term_definitions.items: Additional contextual detail to be applied to all compositions.

The period of care to which this composition belongs. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.
The identifier of the departmental period of care to which this Composition belongs.
Portlet ID from which stores the information where was the composition saved.
The temperature was measured at the buccal mucosa.
The temperature was measured at the sub-lingual mucosa.
Evidence of chills / rigor or shivering.
A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the whole body temperature of the person.
A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the whole body temperature of the person.
The measured body temperature (as a surrogate for the whole body)
The anatomical site of measurement of the temperature
The anatomical site of measurement of the temperature.
Temperature is measured within the mouth
Temperature is measured from within the external auditory canal
Temperature is measured from the skin of the axilla with the arm positioned down by the side
Temperature is measured within the nasopharynx
Temperature is measured in the urinary bladder
Temperature is measured within the vascular system
The thermal situation of the person who is having the temperature taken
The person is covered by a lesser amount of clothing or bedding than deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances
The person is covered by an amount of clothing or bedding deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances
The person is covered by an increased amount of clothing or bedding than deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances
Description of the conditions applied to the subject that might influence their measured body temperature.
Temperature is measured from exposed skin
Temperature is measured within the vagina
Temperatue is measured within the oesophagus
Temperature is measured in the inguinal skin crease between the leg and abdominal wall
Details about the environmental conditions at the time of temperature measurement
Details about the exertion of the person at the time of temperature measurement
Details about the menstrual cycle of a woman
Details about the device use to measure body temperature
Missed beats of greater than 2 per minute
The number of missed beats per minute
The body site where the pulse was measured
Difference between the rate at the heart apex and a peripheral pulse.
Shape of the pulse wave on palpation
The apex beat of the heart (left 5th intercostal space, mid-clavicular line)
The carotid artery in the neck
Missed beats less than 2 per minute
The characteristics of the heart rate and rhythm.
The mechanical heart rate - usually measured by palpation
The mechanical heart rate - usually measured by palpation. Added terms for ZN requirements.
The rate of the heart in beats per minute.
The observed rhythm of the heartbeat.
Heart rhythm is irregular in a chaotic manner.
Comment about the heart rate and rhythm.
The position of the patient when the heartbeat was recorded.
Person reclining at 45 degrees with legs raised.
The heart rate is present (implied true if rate >0).
The heart rate is present (implied true if rate >0).
Details about the device used to measure heart rate and rhythm.
Details about the method or machine used to record the heart rate and rhythm.
Details about physical exertion being undertaken at the time of recording heart rate and/or rhythm.
Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the heart rate and rhythm measurement. For example, level of anxiety; pain or fever etc.
Source of heart rate and rhythm record.
Derived from the electrical activity of the heart, commonly via an electrocardiograph.

Any physical object, product, instrument, apparatus, appliance, material or other item used directly or indirectly in the provision of healthcare, but is not used primarily through therapeutic or metabolic means.
Identification of the device. This is very likely to be a coded field, including pre- or post-coordianted details.
The name of the device manufacturer.
Date that the device/product is no longer fit for use.
Additional details to be noted about the device.
Details about safety feature(s) of the device.
Type of safety feature of the device.
Description of the safety feature of the device.
Size of device - a choice of value types is offered - count, quantity or text.
Is the blood pressure reading suitable to be displayed on a graph?
A non-invasive method was used to record blood pressure.
Locations of invasive measurement of blood pressure.
The left ear of the subject.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm. 'Unsuitable for graphing' added for local Marand ZN use.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
The position of the subject at the time of measurement.
Perloff D, Grim C, Flack J, Frohlich ED, Hill M, McDonald M, Morgenstern BZ. Human blood pressure determination by sphygmomanometry. Circulation 1993;88;2460-2470.
The size of the cuff used for blood pressure measurement.
Common body sites where blood pressure is recorded.
Common body sites where blood pressure is recorded.
A cuff used for an adult thigh - bladder approx 20cm x 42cm.
A cuff for adults with larger arms - bladder approx 16cm x 38cm.
A cuff that is standard for an adult - bladder approx 13cm x 30cm.
The right arm of the person.
The left arm of the person.
The right thigh of the person.
The left thigh of the person.
Standing at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Reclining at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat at the time of blood pressure measurement.
The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying at the time of measurement.
The average arterial pressure that occurs over the entire course of the heart contraction and relaxation cycle.
The difference between the systolic and diastolic pressure.
A cuff used for a small adult - bladder approx 10cm x 24cm.
A cuff that is appropriate for a child or adult with a thin arm - bladder approx 8cm x 21cm.
Record which Korotkoff sound is used for determining diastolic pressure using auscultative method.
The fourth Korotkoff sound is identified as an abrupt muffling of sounds.
The fifth Korotkoff sound is identified by absence of sounds as the cuff pressure drops below the diastolic blood pressure.
Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side. Commonly required in the last trimester of pregnancy to relieve aortocaval compression.
A cuff used for infants - bladder approx 5cm x 15cm.
A cuff used for a neonate, assuming cuff is the appropriate size for maturity and birthweight of the neonate.
The right wrist of the subject.
The left wrist of the subject.
Details about sphygmomanometer or other device used to measure the blood pressure.
The right ankle of the subject.
Details about physical activity undertaken at the time of blood pressure.measurement.
The left ankle of the subject.
A finger of the subject. Identification of the finger can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

Body location where blood pressure is measured. Use 'Location of measurement' to select from common sites. Use 'Specific location' to record more specific details or a site that is not in the common set or to refer to an external terminology.
Specific details about the body site where blood pressure is recorded.
Method of measurement of blood pressure.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).
Formula used to calculate the MAP (if recorded in data).
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.
Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.
Estimate of the average blood pressure over a 24 hour period.
Sleep status - supports interpretation of 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure records.
Subject is in the natural state of bodily rest.
A toe of the subject. Identification of the toe can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the blood pressure measurement. For example, level of anxiety or 'white coat syndrome'; pain or fever; changes in atmospheric pressure etc.
Invasive measurement via transducer access line within an artery. Location of the transducer can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.
Measurement of the body weight of an individual.
Description of the state of dress of the person at the time of weighing.
Clothing which may add significantly to weight, including shoes.
Clothing which will not add to weight significantly.
Wearing only a nappy - can add significant weight.
Comment about the measurement of weight.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of body weight eg timing in menstrual cycle, timing of recent bowel motion or noting of amputation.
Height, or body length, is measured from crown of head to sole of foot. Height is measured with the individual in a standing position and body length in a recumbent position.
Any timed measurement of height or body length.
The length of the body from crown of head to sole of foot.
Description of the device used to measure height or body length.
Height is measured standing on both feet with weight distributed evenly, heels together and both buttocks and heels in contact with a vertical back board.
Comment about the measurement of body height/length.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of body height/length eg noting of amputation.
Length is measured in a fully extended, recumbent position with the pelvis flat, legs extended and feet flexed.
Calculated measurement which compares a person's weight and height.
Any timed recording of Body Mass Index.
Index describing ratio of weight to height.
The method of entering the Body Mass Index.
Body Mass Index calculated and entered automatically without user intervention.
Body Mass Index calculated and entered directly by user.
Formula used to derive the Body Mass Index.
Comment about the Body Mass Index measurement eg noting that the measurements used were adjusted weight/height.
The calculated body surface area of the subject.
The name of the formula employed to calculate Body Surface Area.
The exact formula used to calculate the body surface area.
The Dubois and Dubois formula was used.
The Gehan and George formula was used.
The method of entering the Body Surface Area.
Body Aurface area calculated and entered automatically without user intervention.
Body Surface Area calculated and entered directly by user.
Comment about the Body Surface Area measurement eg noting that the measurements used were adjusted weight/height.
Name of the formula used to calculate lean body mass.
The exact formula used to calculate lean body mass.
Comment about theLean Body Mass measurement eg noting that the measurements used were adjusted weight/height.
Method used to record Lean Body Mass.
Lean Body Mass calculated and entered automatically without user intervention.
Lean Body Mass calculated and entered directly by user.
Lean body mass formula for male subjects was used.
Lean body mass formula for female subjects was used.
The calculated ideal or recommended body mass of the subject.
The method used to derive the ideal body mass recorded.
The name of the formula used to calulate Ideal Body Mass.
The Devine formula, which applies to male subjects, was used in the calculation
The Robertson formula, which applies to female subjects, was used in the calculation
The exact formula used to calculate Ideal Body Weight.
The ideal body mass was calculated automatically.
The ideal body mass was entered directly.
A comment about the calculation method used or confounding factors such as adjusted height /weight/
Measurement of the chest circumference and expansion
The phase of respiration during which the measurement is taken
No account is taken of respiratory phase
The difference in chest circumference from full expiration to full inspiration
Height, or body length, is measured from crown of head to sole of foot. Height is measured with the individual in a standing position and body length in a recumbent position.
Height, or body length, is measured from crown of head to the table surface as the subject sits erect.
Any timed measurement of height or body length.
The length of the body from crown of head to sole of foot.
The length of the body from crown to the surface of the table.
Description of the device used to measure height or body length.
Height is measured standing on both feet with weight distributed evenly, heels together and both buttocks and heels in contact with a vertical back board.
Comment about the measurement of body height/length.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of body height/length eg noting of amputation.
Length is measured in a fully extended, recumbent position with the pelvis flat, legs extended and feet flexed.
The waist (or girth), abdominal and hip circumference.

Defined by WHO as the circumference of the trunk measured midway between the inferior margin of the last rib and the crest of the ilium in a horizontal plane. Equivalent to WHO 'Abdominal circumference'.
Measurement of body circumference at the widest point of the buttocks.
Ratio of waist/abdominal circumference to hip circumference .
The circumference of the widest part of the trunk at the end of normal expiration.
The circumference of the narrowest part of the trunk at the end of normal expiration. Equivalent to WHO 'Waist circumference'
Details of methodology used to measure abdominal/waist circumference.
Measurements related to growth and body shape, according to ZN protocol.
Record information about level of exertion.
The person is at rest, prior to undertaking exercise.
The person is exerting themselves at the time.
Measurement is taken after exertion has ceased.
The phase or context of exercise.
Amount of work being done during exercise.
Semiquantitative description of the intensity of exercise undertaken.
Aspects of patient state which may affect observation results.
The phase of activity being undertaken.
The subject is awake and alert.
Awake, calm / still and watchful / attentive
The position of the subject's body at the time of examination.
Left lateral position (lying on left side)
to raise the head of the patient's bed
Petient is sit ingon someone's lap
For recording findings determined at physical examination.
The description of the examination findings.
The head circumference of the subject.
The head circumference of the subject.
Acts as a container for a set of archetype which represent a single date-capture screen.
Record details about an anatomical location.
Named anatomical location - ideally would be coded where possible.
Specify lateraility of the anatomical location.
Qualifier to identify which direction the anatomical location is in relation to the identified landmark.
Relative location medial to the landmark.
Relative location lateral to the landmark.
Relative location superior to the landmark.
Relative location inferior to the landmark.
In the sagittal plane passing through the midline of the body.
Relative location anterior to the landmark.
Relative location posterior to the landmark.
Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.
Relative location superior and lateral to the landmark.
Relative location inferior and medial to the landmark.
Relative location superior and medial to the landmark.

Qualifiers to identify non-specific location eg 5cm (distance) inferior (aspect) to the tibial tuberosity (landmark). There may be more than one relative location required to provide a cross reference.
Identified anatomical landmark from which to specify relative anatomical location.
Distance of location from the identified landmark.
Line describing the position of a vertical anatomical plane in the body.
In the sagittal plane passing through mid-clavical.
In the coronal plane passing through mid-axilla.
In the sagittal plane passing through mid-scapula.
Identify the specific anatomical site out of multiple eg tenth rib; fourth vertebra; second toe.
Ordinal position 1 of an anatomical location.
Ordinal position 2 of an anatomical location.

The observed characteristics of spontaneous breathing as would commonly be recorded as part of a 'vital signs' examination.
Specific abnormal respiratory pattern. Other patterns may be entered as free text or terminology subset defined at specialisation or template level.
Deep chest breathing with or without a visible gasp.
Periods of hyperventilation alternating with periods of apnoea.
Breathing of varying tidal volumes and rates.
Deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief, insufficient release of breath.
Clusters of irregular breaths that alternate with periods of apnoea. Also termed Biot's breathing.

Subject's level of exertion at or just prior to the observation being made. Intended only to record exertion only as it might effect respirations and where it would not normally be recorded as part of general clinical observation.
The respiratory expiratory phase is longer than normal/usual. Associated with obstructive airways disease such as asthma.
Details of the amount of oxygen being delivered to the subject at the time of observation. Assumed values of 21% oxygen concentration, Fi02 of 0.21 and oxygen flow rate of 0 l/min or 0 ml/min.
Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the respirations observation. For example, level of anxiety, pain, feeding in infants, tracheostomy.
Clusters of breaths separated by intervals of apnea (no breathing) or near-apnea. May also describe a normal patter nof breathing in neonates.
Inflation of the lung during expiration and deflation of the lung during inspiration.

The cause of the apnoea was non-physiological.

In North America the unit for D, co is mL CO/min/mm Hg. The Systeme Internationale unit is mmol/min/kPa, and in Europe the test is called the CO transfer factor. The following equation converts between the 2 units: D, 2.986 X T
Also called carbon monoxide diffusing capacity test .
The maximum capacity of an individual's body to transport and utilize oxygen during incremental exercise.
The ratio of actual to predicted test result.
The agent or physical modality used e.g exercise.
The dose of agent used in the test.
The bronchodilating agent used in the test.
Pulmonary function test that returns a measured volume or caclulated capacity.
A pulmonary function test result expressed as a ratio.
Pulmonary function test that returns a measured flow rate.
The amount of air that can be forced out of the lungs after a maximal inspiration. Emphasis on completeness of expiration. Also termed expiratory vital capacity (EVC) Calculated= IRV+ Vt+ ERV
The volume change of the lung between a full inspiration to total lung capacity and a maximal expiration to residual volume.
The volume of gas contained in the lung after a full inhalation.
The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in one second.
The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in three seconds.
The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in six seconds.
The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in 0.75 of a second.
The maximum flow generated during expiration performed with maximal force and started after a full inspiration. Also termed Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR).
The average flow of air from the lung during the middle portion (25-75%) of expiration (also sometimes referred to as the MMEF, for maximal mid-expiratory flow).
The average flow of air from the lung during the middle portion (25-50%) of expiration (also sometimes referred to as the MMEF, for maximal mid-expiratory flow).
The average flow of air into the lung during the middle portion (25-75%) of inspiration.
The average flow of air into the lung during the middle portion (25-50%) of inspiration.
The maximal volume that can be inspired following a normal expiration. Also termed Inspiratory vital capacity (IVC). Calculated = TV+IRV
The amount of additional air that can be pushed out after the end expiratory level of normal breathing.
The additional air that can be inhaled after a normal tidal breath in.
A measure of the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled and exhaled in one minute. Also termed Maximum ventilation per minute
The ratio of Forced Expiratory volume in 1 second to Inspired vital capacity. Calculated = FEV1/ IVC.
The ration of Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to Forced vital capacity.
The volume of air inspired and then expired from the lung during one respiratory cycle.
The amount of air left in the lungs after a maximal exhalation.
The amount of air left in the lungs after a tidal breath out. Calculated = ERV+RV.

A non-invasive method was used to record blood pressure.
Locations of invasive measurement of blood pressure.
The left ear of the subject.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm. 'Unsuitable for graphing' added for local Marand ZN use.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
The position of the subject at the time of measurement.
Perloff D, Grim C, Flack J, Frohlich ED, Hill M, McDonald M, Morgenstern BZ. Human blood pressure determination by sphygmomanometry. Circulation 1993;88;2460-2470.
The size of the cuff used for blood pressure measurement.
Common body sites where blood pressure is recorded.
Common body sites where blood pressure is recorded.
A cuff used for an adult thigh - bladder approx 20cm x 42cm.
A cuff for adults with larger arms - bladder approx 16cm x 38cm.
A cuff that is standard for an adult - bladder approx 13cm x 30cm.
The right arm of the person.
The left arm of the person.
The right thigh of the person.
The left thigh of the person.
Standing at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Reclining at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat at the time of blood pressure measurement.
The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying at the time of measurement.
The average arterial pressure that occurs over the entire course of the heart contraction and relaxation cycle.
The difference between the systolic and diastolic pressure.
A cuff used for a small adult - bladder approx 10cm x 24cm.
A cuff that is appropriate for a child or adult with a thin arm - bladder approx 8cm x 21cm.
Record which Korotkoff sound is used for determining diastolic pressure using auscultative method.
The fourth Korotkoff sound is identified as an abrupt muffling of sounds.
The fifth Korotkoff sound is identified by absence of sounds as the cuff pressure drops below the diastolic blood pressure.
Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side. Commonly required in the last trimester of pregnancy to relieve aortocaval compression.
A cuff used for infants - bladder approx 5cm x 15cm.
A cuff used for a neonate, assuming cuff is the appropriate size for maturity and birthweight of the neonate.
The right wrist of the subject.
The left wrist of the subject.
Details about sphygmomanometer or other device used to measure the blood pressure.
The right ankle of the subject.
Details about physical activity undertaken at the time of blood pressure.measurement.
The left ankle of the subject.
A finger of the subject. Identification of the finger can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

Body location where blood pressure is measured. Use 'Location of measurement' to select from common sites. Use 'Specific location' to record more specific details or a site that is not in the common set or to refer to an external terminology.
Specific details about the body site where blood pressure is recorded.
Method of measurement of blood pressure.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).
Formula used to calculate the MAP (if recorded in data).
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.
Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.
Estimate of the average blood pressure over a 24 hour period.
Sleep status - supports interpretation of 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure records.
Subject is in the natural state of bodily rest.
A toe of the subject. Identification of the toe can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the blood pressure measurement. For example, level of anxiety or 'white coat syndrome'; pain or fever; changes in atmospheric pressure etc.
Invasive measurement via transducer access line within an artery. Location of the transducer can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

Details of the amount of oxygen being delivered to the subject at the time of observation. Assumed values of 21% oxygen concentration, Fi02 of 0.21 and oxygen flow rate of 0 l/min or 0 ml/min.

In North America the unit for D, co is mL CO/min/mm Hg. The Systeme Internationale unit is mmol/min/kPa, and in Europe the test is called the CO transfer factor. The following equation converts between the 2 units: D, 2.986 X T

The amount of air that can be forced out of the lungs after a maximal inspiration. Emphasis on completeness of expiration. Also termed expiratory vital capacity (EVC) Calculated= IRV+ Vt+ ERV
The volume change of the lung between a full inspiration to total lung capacity and a maximal expiration to residual volume.
The volume of gas contained in the lung after a full inhalation.
The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in one second.

The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in 0.75 of a second.
The maximum flow generated during expiration performed with maximal force and started after a full inspiration. Also termed Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR).

The average flow of air from the lung during the middle portion (25-50%) of expiration (also sometimes referred to as the MMEF, for maximal mid-expiratory flow).
The average flow of air into the lung during the middle portion (25-75%) of inspiration.
The average flow of air into the lung during the middle portion (25-50%) of inspiration.
The maximal volume that can be inspired following a normal expiration. Also termed Inspiratory vital capacity (IVC). Calculated = TV+IRV
The amount of additional air that can be pushed out after the end expiratory level of normal breathing.
The additional air that can be inhaled after a normal tidal breath in.
A measure of the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled and exhaled in one minute. Also termed Maximum ventilation per minute
The ratio of Forced Expiratory volume in 1 second to Inspired vital capacity. Calculated = FEV1/ IVC.
The ration of Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to Forced vital capacity.
The volume of air inspired and then expired from the lung during one respiratory cycle.
The amount of air left in the lungs after a maximal exhalation.
The amount of air left in the lungs after a tidal breath out. Calculated = ERV+RV.

To record the result of a laboratory test which may be used to record a single valued test but will often be specialised or templated to represent multiple value or 'panel' tests. This archetype also acts as the parent for specialisations appropriate for more specific laboratory tests microbiology, histopathology.
